comments.commentBody: Or, maybe they were fired when they dared to speak out against the "company line;"  See, e.g. David Frum

It's about time these two guys were exposed. AEI has become an institution of shaky distinction lately. It refused to weigh in on health reform, even though its own ideas were being advocated by Obama; its 'scholars' helped make the case for invading Iraq, and continue to this day defending that hapless, reckless, clueless foreign policy blunder; and now this obsession with Fannie and Freddie, as though the rest of the U.S. banking industry resided somewhere in outer space during the subprime debacle. I know there are smart people somewhere at this institution; are they scared to emerge, or just embarrassed?

Don't forget to arrest the appraisers. During the run up, the auctioneers (the real estate industry) were able to back the bidders up to "no limit". Higher bids became a self-fulfilling prophecy. But only because the appraisers let it happen. Bank appraisers are basically bank lackeys who require little training to rubberstamp everything that works towards the banks goal of inflating the price of real estate.

As you (and I in response) have said before, the Great Recession was not brought on by Fannie and Freddie. However, they were late but willing enablers; as were both sides of congressional aisles.

The primary culprits really were the real estate professionals and the banks who first allowed subprime mortgages to begin with; then, contrary to law and regulation with the force of law, ignored documentation requirements while foisting these abominations on everyone they could, to boost fees; then, who created arcane hedging/investment instruments that mixed highly questionable mortgages with sound ones and sold them globally as if they were gilt-edged. Dante should have invented a separate bolgia in the Inferno for such people.

But, to the extent that these very bad people needed encouragement (they really didn't need much), Fannie and Freddie, egged on and pressured by U.S. Senators and Representatives on both sides of the aisle who wanted to facilitate home ownership without any regard to potential consequences, gave them that encouragement, late in the process but nevertheless volubly.

But before I indicted Fannie and Freddie executives, I'd indict just about every real estate agent and lawyer in the country, and the boards and management of every single "too big to fail" bank and investment house.

The old fashioned deposit-based bank lending model is wrecked by central bankers creating interest rate risk motivated by faulty monetary theory and the potential profits from front-running their own interest rate manipulations.
We are the only major country in the world where the government gets involved in the mortgage market.
Easy to fix. Simply require that any bank desiring FDIC surety on its deposits provide a % of its business as residential mortgages. Done.

"... the country would be well served by a real debate about the role of government in housing."

This might be a good topic for a series of columns.

I don't know much about the complexities of CDOs and MBS, but I would guess that without some government backing, the mortgage market would be close to nothing. Big banks (if mortgages were handled only in the old fashioned way) simply would not take the risk. Maybe smaller, community and regional banks would. Maybe not.

And if one of the factors holding the economy back is the huge private debt overhang, then getting rid of Fannie and Freddie (and possibly any other government support) would make the housing market worse.

"Three years after the financial crisis, the country would be well served by a real debate about the role of government in housing. Should the government be helping low- and moderate-income Americans own their own homes? If so, is there an acceptable level of risk? If not, how do we recast the American dream?"

I thought we had this debate, long ago. In fact, it's been well-known within minority communities for decades that access to credit for home loans, small business loans and others was always easier for non-minorities. The Republican-hated mandates of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were answers to this paucity for potential, deserving minority borrowers. The institutional biases of the private banking sector only showed the sector was willing to make indiscriminate loans available to many UNdeserving candidates once they figured out they could quickly move the loans off their own books, shovel the garbage to unwitting investors and bet against those same loans at a high profit.

I greatly appreciate the light Mr. Nocera sheds on the intellectual dishonesty of AEI and other supposedly "scientific" policy advisors and researchers; however, I lament the fact that they've so successfully perpetrated their misinformation campaign that Mr. Nocera must make go back to arguing such government balancing is necessary. The problem with most government programs is that while the people want the benefits, the right wing of the Republican party doesn't want it to appear that the government is providing them. So we get Congress telling GSE's to help provide affordable housing by buying more mortgages on the secondary market (or, even more removed, securities based on affordable mortgages) so that the private market can "provide affordable housing". To pretend that the government is not helping, the program is complicated and very inefficient.

The biggest housing program is the mortgage interest deduction that subsidizes wealthy homeowners; because it's a deduction, the same amount interest is worth more to people in higher income brackets, and lower income homeowners are ineligible, because most don't itemize their deductions. So while the Republican meme is that the government intervention in housing generally benefits lazy poor people, the reality is that most government assistance allows the wealthy to afford McMansions.

We should convert the mortgage interest deduction to a housing credit, with each head of household getting a credit on their taxes of a few thousand a year instead of rich homeowners with big mortgages getting to reduce their tax bills by tens of thousands, while the poor (and the renters) get nothing. A tax credit that was worth the same to every head of household would eliminate the distorting impact of the mortgage interest deduction, and revive the affordable market.
